awd_titl_txt: A Southern Hemispheric Perspective on Holocene Climate Variability Based on Mountain Glacial Chronologies
awd_abstract_narration:
Mountain glaciers respond sensitively to changes in Earth's atmosphere such that records of their history serve as a useful proxy for past climates.  Thus, comprehensive records of glacier extents can be combined with other types of climate archives to provide a perspective from the past on the present controls on the climate system.  This project will build on recent observations by the researchers, who found that glacier-climate histories at the southern tip of South America showed different patterns from those observed in North America and Europe.  Based on these observations, this research will examine recent variability in glaciers and climates along middle to high latitudinal gradients in the Southern Hemisphere, which can be used to test hypotheses regarding factors that controlled glacier activities prior to instrumental records of climate. Thus, this perspective of glacier sensitivity to past climate changes will help improve our understanding of present and projected climate changes.  The researchers will collaborate with scientists from Chile and Argentina, bringing together international expertise to accomplish the research goals, which may inform regional and global societal implications for water and hydroelectric resources and local cultural significance.  The team will include both undergraduate and graduate students, including collaboration with a graduate student from the Medill School of Journalism who will join the field research to produce a media package that will be of broad public interest. The researchers will also engage K-12 science teachers and their students through the Earth2Class program.

This research will test hypotheses that will illuminate the spatial and temporal variability of paleoclimate signals and the interaction of polar and non-polar controls on regional and global climates.  The project will determine how past variability in glaciers and climate varied along latitude in the Southern Hemisphere.  Specifically, the project will: 1) map glacial features and collect samples from at least three sites in South America; 2) employ 14-C and state-of-the-art 10-Be dating on landforms as young as the historical record (to test reliability), 3) collaborate with climate-glacier modeling experts to reconstruct equilibrium line altitudes and back out the causal temperature and precipitation changes; 4) collaborate with a global climate modeler to provide insight into possible regional and hemispherical forcings, and 5) integrate findings into larger interdisciplinary efforts. This multi-faceted approach will improve understanding of temporal and spatial variability, sensitivity and response of glaciers to past climate changes.  This understanding of the history of glacier responses to climate change will provide perspective on our understanding of present changes, and provide test data sets for global climate models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Despite ongoing, near worldwide, glacier recession (“in sync” recession) - attributed at least in part to anthropogenic warming - 'paleo' or past observations indicate natural variability of glacier and climate behavior (after the end of the last Ice Age) differed spatially around South America, the Southern Hemisphere and between the hemispheres. This includes findings in publications that are an outcome of research supported with this award. In this project, overall objectives were to provide data and findings in the Southern Hemisphere to test hypotheses centered on glacier variability, sensitivity and responses, and possible climate drivers (“forcings”) prior to instrumental observations.

In more detial, our aim is to understand better how glaciers and climates changed in the past from high to low latitudes of the Southern Hemisphere. Glacier-climate archives provide a perspective from the past on the climate forcings at different time scales. A goal is to document and understand better the “natural variability” or past context of present glacier and climate behavior, from the colder Subantarctic towards the warmer subtropics of the Southern Hemisphere. Moreover, to reconstruct past glacier behavior during cold as well as warm periods. The time of focus is the last ~12,000 years or since the end of the last Ice Age, a period referred to as the Holocene epoch. Our efforts involved several major field campaigns in the southern and central Andes, laboratory analyses on samples collected in the field, combined with  documenting and understanding geologic or geomorphic context. We obtained unique datasets that directly bear on the history of glacier and climate behavior in South America.

Prior to our project, our group and others found that past climates over the middle-high latitudes of the Southern Hemisphere, including on the Antarctic Peninsula, differed from the Northern Hemisphere. During this project, we extended such results and findings northward from southernmost South America. In central-northern Patagonia, we found a similar pattern of glacier and climate history as the higher latitudes of southern Patagonia, which are impacted by the Subantarctic or polar regimes. Glaciers were largest in the middle Holocene, 7,000 to 5,000 years ago, unlike that in Europe and North America. This implies the coldest summer temperatures of the Holocene were not during recent centuries but earlier (unlike the Holocene “Little Ice Age” in Europe). Although, there is a devil in the details, as some minor secondary differences are found compared with higher latitudes of Patagonia. We hypothesize these secondary differences are found with distance from higher latitude dominant Subantarctic climate regimes. 

In contrast, in areas affected more by subtropical climates, 34-35°S, we found the natural variability of glacier activities and thus past climates are different than in higher latitudes of Patagonia. We are obtaining some of the first 10Be cosmogenic ages for glacier and paleoclimate records (with support of this award) in the central Andes. The results indicate that, unlike Patagonia to the south, no glacier expansions are observed in the middle Holocene, but instead mainly over the last ~1000 years. This is a key finding of the project. Perhaps records to the north of Patagonia are more similar to those in the tropics and Northern Hemisphere.

In terms of the geological context of current changes, we found glacier records in central Patagonia are unlike those in the Northern Hemisphere, but similar to other records in the middle to high latitudes of the Southern Hemisphere. That is, recent Anthropogenic climate changes have caused hemispheres to be in sync, whereas longer-term Holocene records show distinct differences in glacier histories, even within South America.

In terms of broader impacts, understanding the history of glaciers and past climates in the Andes and Southern Hemisphere are of interest to other scientists and society for several reasons. The most important is that prior to the 20th century, longer-term geologic records show distinct differences in glacier and climate histories, even regionally within South America. We also pushed the envelope in terms of our analyses over recent time scales, that is, the last few hundred years, which benefits future research. In terms of other broader impacts, the project has provided several researchers at different career stages, including graduate students and postdocs, with new research experiences and expertise. It has involved strong international collaborations with Chilean and Argentine scientists including early-career graduate and undergraduate students. Those involved engaged with scientific and non-scientific audiences.
